cards.name: Seraph Sanctuary
cards.text:
When Seraph Sanctuary enters the battlefield, you gain 1 life.
Whenever an Angel enters the battlefield under your control, you gain 1 life.
{T}: Add {C}.
cards.originalText:
When Seraph Sanctuary enters the battlefield, you gain 1 life.
Whenever an Angel enters the battlefield under your control, you gain 1 life.
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Slayers' Stronghold
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{R}{W}, {T}: Target creature gets +2/+0 and gains vigilance and haste until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Its courtyards are lit during every hour of the day so that night may never fall within its walls.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{R}{W}, {T}: Target creature gets +2/+0 and gains vigilance and haste until end of turn.

cards.name: Plains
cards.originalText: W

cards.originalText: W

cards.name: Plains
cards.originalText: W

cards.originalText: U

cards.originalText: U

cards.originalText: B

cards.originalText: B

cards.originalText: B

cards.name: Mountain
cards.originalText: R

cards.name: Forest
cards.originalText: G

cards.name: Forest
cards.originalText: G

cards.name: Forest
cards.originalText: G

cards.name: Amulet of Kroog
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor: Among the first allies Urza gained were the people of Kroog. As a sign of friendship, Urza gave the healers of the city potent amulets; afterwards, thousands journeyed to Kroog in hope of healing, greatly adding to the city's glory.
cards.originalText: {2}: Prevent 1 damage to any target.

cards.name: Armageddon Clock
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a doom counter on Armageddon Clock.
At the beginning of your draw step, Armageddon Clock deals damage equal to the number of doom counters on it to each player.
{4}: Remove a doom counter from Armageddon Clock. Any player may activate this ability but only during any upkeep step.

rulings.text: Players can remove as many counters as they can pay for each turn.

cards.originalText: Put one counter on Armageddon Clock during each of your upkeeps. At the end of your upkeep, each player takes damage equal to the number of counters on the Clock. Any player may spend {4} during any upkeep to remove a counter.

cards.name: Ashnod's Altar
cards.text: Sacrifice a creature: Add {C}{C}.
cards.originalText: {0}: Sacrifice one of your creatures to add 2 colorless mana to your mana pool. This effect is played as an interrupt. You may not sacrifice a creature that is already on its way to the graveyard.

cards.name: Ashnod's Battle Gear
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Ashnod's Battle Gear during your untap step.
{2}, {T}: Target creature you control gets +2/-2 for as long as Ashnod's Battle Gear remains tapped.
cards.flavor: This horrid invention clearly illustrates why Mishra's lieutenant was feared as much by her troops as by her foes.
cards.originalText: {2}: Give a creature of yours +2/-2 as long as Ashnod's Battle Gear is tapped. You may choose not to untap Ashnod's Battle Gear during untap phase.

cards.name: Ashnod's Transmogrant
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Ashnod's Transmogrant: Put a +1/+1 counter on target nonartifact creature. That creature becomes an artifact in addition to its other types.
cards.flavor: Ashnod found few willing to trade their humanity for the power she offered them.

rulings.text: It's the ability, not the counter that makes the creature an artifact. The creature remains an artifact even if the +1/+1 counter is removed.

cards.originalText: Target non-artifact creature gains +1/+1 and is now considered an artifact creature, though it retains its original color. Discard Ashnod's Transmogrant after it is used.

cards.name: Battering Ram
cards.text:
At the beginning of combat on your turn, Battering Ram gains banding until end of combat. (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's blocking.)
Whenever Battering Ram becomes blocked by a Wall, destroy that Wall at end of combat.
cards.flavor: By the time Mishra was defeated, no mage was foolish enough to rely heavily on walls.

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Bands, but only when attacking. Any wall blocking Battering Ram is destroyed. Walls destroyed this way deal their damage before dying.

cards.name: Bronze Tablet
cards.text:
Remove Bronze Tablet from your deck before playing if you're not playing for ante.
Bronze Tablet enters the battlefield tapped.
{4}, {T}: Exile Bronze Tablet and target nontoken permanent an opponent owns. That player may pay 10 life. If they do, put Bronze Tablet into its owner's graveyard. Otherwise, that player owns Bronze Tablet and you own the other exiled card.

rulings.text: If using a copy of the Tablet, you must trade the copy card to your opponent just like you would have traded the Tablet.
You can't choose to pay 10 life if you have less than 10 life, but you may choose to give up the game immediately. This has roughly the same effect.
You can take control of your opponent's Tablet and in the trade you only have to give them back their Tablet.
If the card being targeted by the Bronze Tablet is removed before Tablet takes effect, then the Tablet ability doesn't resolve and it remains tapped.

If the tablet is not still on the battlefield when the ability resolves, it is not exiled. The other player still has the choice to pay 10 life, and you still become the owner of their card if they choose not to do so.

cards.originalText: {4}: Target any card opponent has in play; remove it and Bronze Tablet from game. You become owner of that card, and your opponent becomes owner of Bronze Tablet. Exchange is permanent; play as interrupt. Opponent can prevent exchange by spending 10 life; this discards Bronze Tablet. Damage-preventing effects cannot counter such loss of life. Bronze Tablet comes into play tapped. Remove this card from deck if not playing for ante.

cards.name: Candelabra of Tawnos
cards.text: {X}, {T}: Untap X target lands.
cards.flavor: Tawnos learned quickly from Urza that utter simplicity often led to wondrous, yet subtle utility.

rulings.text: You may untap your opponent's lands if desired.
Can be used on an untapped land.
This is not mana ability. It is a normal ability and it will resolve along with other spells and abilities on the stack. The lands untap during resolution.

cards.originalText: {X}: Untap X separate lands.

cards.name: Clay Statue
cards.text: {2}: Regenerate Clay Statue.
cards.flavor: Tawnos won fame as Urza's greatest assistant. After he created these warriors, Urza ended his apprenticeship, promoting him directly to the rank of master.
cards.originalText: {2}: Regenerates

cards.name: Clockwork Avian
cards.text:
Flying
Clockwork Avian enters the battlefield with four +1/+0 counters on it.
At end of combat, if Clockwork Avian attacked or blocked this combat, remove a +1/+0 counter from it.
{X}, {T}: Put up to X +1/+0 counters on Clockwork Avian. This ability can't cause the total number of +1/+0 counters on Clockwork Avian to be greater than four. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.

rulings.text: Loses a counter even if it is affected by a Fog-like effect which prevents it from dealing damage.
Can attack or block even if it has no counters.
If the ability to add counters resolves when there are already the maximum number of counters on it, any counters over the maximum are simply not added.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Put four +1/+0 counters on Avian. After Avian attacks or blocks a creature, discard a counter.
During his or her upkeep, controller may buy back lost counters for {1} per counter; this taps Avian.

cards.name: Colossus of Sardia
cards.text:
Trample (This creature can deal excess combat damage to the player or planeswalker it's attacking.)
Colossus of Sardia doesn't untap during your untap step.
{9}: Untap Colossus of Sardia. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.
cards.flavor:
From the Sardian mountains wakes ancient doom:
Warrior born from a rocky womb.

rulings.text: The ability that untaps it during your upkeep has been returned to an activated ability. There is no restriction on how many times it can be untapped during your upkeep with this ability.

cards.originalText:
Trample
Colossus does not untap normally during untap phase; you may spend {9} during your upkeep phase to untap Colossus.

cards.name: Coral Helm
cards.text: {3}, Discard a card at random: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.originalText: {3}: Give target creature +2/+2 until end of turn. Each time you use this ability, you must discard one card at random from your hand. Coral Helm cannot be used if you have no cards in your hand.

cards.name: Cursed Rack
cards.text:
As Cursed Rack enters the battlefield, choose an opponent.
The chosen player's maximum hand size is four.
cards.flavor: Ashnod invented several torture techniques that could make victims even miles away beg for mercy as if the End had come.

rulings.text: The effect of lowering the maximum hand size makes it so the player discards down to 4 cards (instead of the usual 7) during the cleanup step.

You choose one opposing player just as this card is entering the battlefield and it only affects that one player. This choice is not changed even if this card changes controllers. It becomes useless but stays on the battlefield if the chosen player leaves the game.

If multiple effects modify your hand size, apply them in timestamp order. For example, if you put Null Profusion (an enchantment that says your maximum hand size is two) onto the battlefield and then a player puts Cursed Rack onto the battlefield choosing you, your maximum hand size will be four. However, if those permanents entered the battlefield in the opposite order, your maximum hand size would be two.

cards.originalText: Opponent must discard down to four cards during his or her discard phase.

cards.name: Dragon Engine
cards.text: {2}: Dragon Engine gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Those who believed the city of Kroog would never fall to Mishra's forces severely underestimated the might of his war machines.
cards.originalText: {2}: +1/+0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Feldon's Cane
cards.text: {T}, Exile Feldon's Cane: Shuffle your graveyard into your library.
cards.flavor: Feldon found the first of these canes frozen in the Ronom Glacier.
cards.originalText: {0}: Reshuffle your graveyard into your library. If Feldon's Cane is used, remove it from the game, returning it to its owner's deck only when the game is over.

cards.name: Golgothian Sylex
cards.text: {1}, {T}: Each nontoken permanent with a name originally printed in the Antiquities expansion is sacrificed by its controller.
cards.flavor: From their earliest educations, the brothers had known that no human contrivance could stand against the true masters of Dominia.
cards.originalText: {1}: All cards from the Antiquities expansion, including Golgothian Sylex, must be discarded from play.

cards.name: Grapeshot Catapult
cards.text: {T}: Grapeshot Catapult deals 1 damage to target creature with flying.
cards.flavor: For years scholars debated whether these were Urza's or Mishra's creations. Recent research suggests they were invented by the brothers' original master, Tocasia, and that both used these devices.
cards.originalText: Tap to deal 1 damage to target flying creature.

cards.name: Ivory Tower
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you gain X life, where X is the number of cards in your hand minus 4.
cards.flavor: Valuing scholarship above all else, the inhabitants of the Ivory Tower reward those who sacrifice power for knowledge.

rulings.text: If you have four or fewer cards in your hand when Ivory Tower's ability resolves, the ability has no effect.

cards.originalText: During your upkeep phase, gain 1 life for each card in your hand above four.

cards.name: Jalum Tome
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: This timeworn relic was responsible for many of Urza's victories, though he never fully comprehended its mystical runes.
cards.originalText: {2}: Draw a card from your library, then immediately discard a card of your choice to your graveyard.

cards.name: Mightstone
cards.text: Attacking creatures get +1/+0.
cards.flavor: While exploring the sacred cave of Koilos with his brother Mishra and their master Tocasia, Urza fell behind in the Hall of Tagsin, where he discovered the remarkable Mightstone.

rulings.text: The +1/+0 applies to attacking creatures from all players.

cards.originalText: All attacking creatures gain +1/+0.

cards.name: Millstone
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Target player puts the top two cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: More than one mage was driven insane by the sound of the Millstone relentlessly grinding away.

rulings.text: Can be used on a player with less than 2 cards in their library. It will remove 0 or 1 cards if that is all that is available.
It is not a draw effect so it will not cause a player with less than 2 cards in their library to lose.
Since you are putting more than one card in the graveyard at one time, the affected player can choose the order the 2 cards go in.

cards.originalText: {2}: Take the top two cards from target player's library and put them in target player's graveyard.

cards.name: Mishra's War Machine
cards.text:
Banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
At the beginning of your upkeep, Mishra's War Machine deals 3 damage to you unless you discard a card. If Mishra's War Machine deals damage to you this way, tap it.

rulings.text: You may choose to take damage or to discard. You can't avoid taking damage if you have no cards to discard.

If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText:
Bands
During your upkeep, discard one card of your choice from your hand, or Mishra's War Machine becomes tapped and does 3 points of damage to you.

cards.name: Obelisk of Undoing
cards.text: {6}, {T}: Return target permanent you both own and control to your hand.
cards.flavor: The Battle of Tomakul taught Urza not to rely on fickle reinforcements.
cards.originalText: {6}: Return any of your permanents in play to your hand; enchantments on that permanent are discarded. Can be used only on permanents you cast.

cards.name: Onulet
cards.text: When Onulet dies, you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: An early inspiration for Urza, Tocasia's Onulets contained magical essences that could be cannibalized after they stopped functioning.
cards.originalText: If Onulet goes to the graveyard, its controller gains 2 life.

cards.name: Ornithopter
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor: Many scholars believe that these creatures were the result of Urza's first attempt at mechanical life, perhaps created in his early days as an apprentice to Tocasia.
cards.originalText: Flying

cards.name: Primal Clay
cards.text: As Primal Clay enters the battlefield, it becomes your choice of a 3/3 artifact creature, a 2/2 artifact creature with flying, or a 1/6 Wall artifact creature with defender in addition to its other types. (A creature with defender can't attack.)

rulings.text: In zones other than the battlefield, this creature card is 0/0.

If another permanent enters the battlefield as a copy of this creature, the controller of that permanent will get to make a new choice. The copy won't necessarily have the same power, toughness, and abilities as the original.
If a creature that's already on the battlefield becomes a copy of this creature, it copies the power, toughness, and abilities that were chosen for this creature as it entered the battlefield.

cards.originalText: When you cast Primal Clay, you must choose whether to make it a 1/6 wall, a 3/3 creature, or a 2/2 flying creature. Primal Clay then remains in this form until altered by another card or removed from play.

cards.name: Rakalite
cards.text: {2}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn. Return Rakalite to its owner's hand at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor: Urza was the first to understand that the war would not be lost for lack of power, but for lack of troops.

rulings.text: Only returns to your hand if it is still on the battlefield at the end of the turn. If it leaves the battlefield, it does not return.
Can be used any number of times during the turn before it leaves the battlefield.

cards.originalText: {2}: Prevent 1 damage to any target. If Rakalite is used, it returns to its owner's hand at end of turn; all enchantments on Rakalite are then discarded.

cards.name: Rocket Launcher
cards.text: {2}: Rocket Launcher deals 1 damage to any target. Destroy Rocket Launcher at the beginning of the next end step. Activate this ability only if you've controlled Rocket Launcher continuously since the beginning of your most recent turn.
cards.flavor: What these devices lacked in subtlety, they made up in strength.

rulings.text: You can choose different targets for each use.
Because it does not have tapping as part of its activation cost, you can activate the ability many times in one turn, but it is destroyed at the end of any turn in which you use it.
It is only destroyed at end of turn if the ability resolved. If the ability is countered, it is not sacrificed.

cards.originalText: {2}: Do 1 damage to any target. Rocket Launcher may not be used until it begins a turn in play on your side. If it is used, Rocket Launcher is destroyed at end of turn.

cards.name: Shapeshifter
cards.text:
As Shapeshifter enters the battlefield, choose a number between 0 and 7.
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may choose a number between 0 and 7.
Shapeshifter's power is equal to the last chosen number and its toughness is equal to 7 minus that number.
cards.flavor:
Born like a Phoenix from the Flame,
But neither Bulk nor Shape the same.
—Jonathan Swift, "Vanbrug's House"

rulings.text: The ability that sets its power and toughness is a characteristic-defining ability. This means it applies before any other effects that modify power and/or toughness.
The ability that lets you choose a new number is a triggered ability that triggers only once each upkeep.

cards.originalText: The *s below represent any number from 0 to 6. You set * when Shapeshifter is cast, and you may change it during your upkeep.

cards.name: Staff of Zegon
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Target creature gets -2/-0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Though Mishra was impressed by the staves Ashnod had created for Zegon's defense, he understood they only hinted at her full potential.
cards.originalText: {3}: Target creature loses -2/-0 until end of turn. Creatures with power less than 1 deal no damage.

cards.name: Su-Chi
cards.text: When Su-Chi dies, add {C}{C}{C}{C}.
cards.flavor: Flawed copies of relics from the Thran Empire, the Su-Chi were inherently unstable but provided useful knowledge for Tocasia's students.

rulings.text: You get the mana whether you want it or not. If you don't spend it, it will disappear at the end of the current step (or phase).

cards.originalText: If Su-Chi goes to the graveyard, its controller gains 4 colorless mana.

cards.name: Tablet of Epityr
cards.text: Whenever an artifact you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may pay {1}. If you do, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: Originally considered the work of Urza, this tablet was created by forgers seeking to imitate Urza's masterpieces.
cards.originalText: {1}: You gain 1 life every time one of your artifacts goes to the graveyard. Can only give 1 life each time an artifact reaches the graveyard.

cards.name: Tawnos's Coffin
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Tawnos's Coffin during your untap step.
{3}, {T}: Exile target creature and all Auras attached to it. Note the number and kind of counters that were on that creature. When Tawnos's Coffin leaves the battlefield or becomes untapped, return that exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control tapped with the noted number and kind of counters on it. If you do, return the other exiled cards to the battlefield under their owner's control attached to that permanent.

rulings.text: The creature returns to the battlefield tapped. It does not return to the battlefield and then tap afterwards.
If the targeted creature is a token, it will cease to exist after being exiled. Any Auras that were attached to it will remain exiled forever.
If the exiled card is returned to the battlefield and, for some reason, it now can't be enchanted by an Aura that was also exiled by Tawnos's Coffin, that Aura will remain exiled.
If Tawnos's Coffin leaves the battlefield before its ability has resolved, it will exile the targeted creature forever, since its delayed triggered ability will never trigger.
Because the new wording doesn't use phasing, the exiled card will suffer from summoning sickness upon its return to the battlefield.
The effect doesn't care what types the card has after it is exiled, only that it have been a creature while on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: {3}: Select a creature in play; that creature is considered out of play as long as Coffin remains tapped. Hence the creature cannot be the target of spells and cannot receive damage, use special powers, attack, or defend. All counters and enchantments on the creature remain but are also out of play. If Coffin is untapped or removed, creature returns to play tapped. You may choose not to untap Coffin during the untap phase.

cards.name: Tawnos's Wand
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Target creature with power 2 or less can't be blocked this turn.
cards.originalText: {2}: Make a creature of power no greater than 2 unblockable by all creatures except artifact creatures until end of turn. Other cards may be used to increase target creature's power beyond 2 after defense is chosen.

cards.name: Tawnos's Weaponry
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Tawnos's Weaponry during your untap step.
{2}, {T}: Target creature gets +1/+1 for as long as Tawnos's Weaponry remains tapped.
cards.flavor: When Urza's war machines became too costly, Tawnos's weaponry replaced them.
cards.originalText: {2}: Target creature gains +1/+1 as long as Tawnos's Weaponry remains tapped. You may choose not to untap Tawnos's Weaponry during untap phase.

cards.name: Tetravus
cards.text:
Flying
Tetravus enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may remove any number of +1/+1 counters from Tetravus. If you do, create that many 1/1 colorless Tetravite artifact creature tokens. They each have flying and "This creature can't be enchanted."
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may exile any number of tokens created with Tetravus. If you do, put that many +1/+1 counters on Tetravus.

rulings.text: If the Tetravus is destroyed when the Tetravites are off the card, they are not destroyed, they are just orphaned.
Any +1/+1 counter which is on this card can be turned into a Tetravite token. It does not care where the +1/+1 counter came from.
Only Tetravites from this specific Tetravus may be used for the ability. Ones from a different Tetravus can't.
This card now has two upkeep-triggered abilities. Its controller chooses the order they are put on the stack, and thus the order in which they resolve each upkeep.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Tetravus gets three +1/+1 counters when cast. During your upkeep, you may move each of these counters on or off Tetravus.  Counters moved off of Tetravus become independent 1/1 flying artifact creatures.  If such a creature dies, the counter is removed from play.  Such creatures may not have enchantments cast on them, and they do not share any enchantments on Tetravus.

cards.name: The Rack
cards.text:
As The Rack enters the battlefield, choose an opponent.
At the beginning of the chosen player's upkeep, The Rack deals X damage to that player, where X is 3 minus the number of cards in their hand.
cards.flavor: Invented in Mishra's earlier days, the Rack was once his most feared creation.

rulings.text: You choose one opposing player as this card enters the battlefield and it only affects that one player. This choice is not changed even if this card changes controllers. It becomes useless but stays on the battlefield if the chosen player leaves the game.

cards.originalText: If opponent has fewer than three cards in hand during his or her upkeep, the Rack does 1 damage to opponent for each card fewer than three.

cards.name: Triskelion
cards.text:
Triskelion enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Triskelion: It deals 1 damage to any target.
cards.flavor: A brainchild of Tawnos, the Triskelion proved its versatility and usefulness in many of the later battles between the brothers.

rulings.text: If you activate the ability of an attacking or blocking Triskelion during the declare blockers step, it will deal less combat damage as a result. If you wait until the combat damage step, but Triskelion is dealt lethal damage, it'll be destroyed before you get a chance to activate its ability.

If Triskelion has damage marked on it, activating its ability may cause that damage to become lethal. For example, say a Triskelion with two +1/+1 counters on it has been dealt 2 damage earlier in the turn. If you activate its ability by removing a +1/+1 counter from it, it now has 2 toughness and is destroyed as a state-based action. You won't be able to remove the other +1/+1 counter from it to activate its ability again. The first activation of the ability will still resolve.

cards.originalText: Triskelion gets three +1/+1 counters when cast. Controller may discard a +1/+1 counter at any time to do 1 damage to any target.

cards.name: Urza's Avenger
cards.text: {0}: Urza's Avenger gets -1/-1 and gains your choice of banding, flying, first strike, or trample until end of turn. (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor: Unable to settle on just one design, Urza decided to create one versatile being.

rulings.text: The -1/-1 is not permanent. It lasts until the end of the turn as do the abilities that are granted.

cards.originalText: {0}: Avenger loses -1/-1 and gains one of your choice of flying, banding, first strike, or trample until end of turn. Attribute losses and ability gains are cumulative.

cards.name: Urza's Chalice
cards.text: Whenever a player casts an artifact spell, you may pay {1}. If you do, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: When sorely wounded or tired, Urza would often retreat to the workshops of his apprentices. They were greatly amazed at how much better he looked each time he took a sip of water.

rulings.text: This will not trigger on its own casting. It must be on the battlefield at the time the artifact is cast.

cards.originalText: {1}: Any artifact cast by any player gives you 1 life. Can only give 1 life each time an artifact is cast.

cards.name: Urza's Miter
cards.text: Whenever an artifact you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, if it wasn't sacrificed, you may pay {3}. If you do, draw a card.
cards.originalText: {3}: Draw one card from your library every time an artifact of yours goes to the graveyard. Can only let you draw one card per artifact destruction. May not be used when you destroy an artifact to gain benefits from another card.

cards.name: Wall of Spears
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
First strike
cards.flavor: Even the most conservative generals revised their tactics after the Battle of Sarinth, during which a handful of peasant-pikemen held off a trio of rampaging Craw Wurms.
cards.originalText: First strike, counts as a wall.

cards.name: Weakstone
cards.text: Attacking creatures get -1/-0.
cards.flavor: During the brothers' childhood, Tocasia took them to explore the sacred cave of Koilos. There, in the Hall of Tagsin, Mishra discovered the mysterious weakstone.

rulings.text: The -1/-0 applies to attacking creatures from all players.

cards.originalText: All attacking creatures lose -1/-0. Creatures with power less than 1 deal no damage.

cards.name: Yotian Soldier
cards.text: Vigilance
cards.flavor: After Kroog was destroyed while most of its defenders were at his side, Urza vowed that none of his allies would ever need to fear for their own defense again, even while laying siege to a city far from their homes.
cards.originalText: Attacking does not cause Yotian Soldier to tap.

cards.name: Artifact Possession
cards.text:
Enchant artifact
Whenever enchanted artifact becomes tapped or a player activates an ability of enchanted artifact without {T} in its activation cost, Artifact Possession deals 2 damage to that artifact's controller.
cards.flavor: Any black mage could coax a Thraxodemon to inhabit a magical device.
cards.originalText: Artifact Possession does 2 damage to target artifact's controller each time target artifact is tapped or its activation cost is paid. Has no effect if cast on a continuous artifact.

cards.name: Drafna's Restoration
cards.text: Put any number of target artifact cards from target player's graveyard on top of their library in any order.
cards.flavor: Drafna, founder of the College of Lat-Nam, could create a working model from even the smallest remnants of a newly unearthed artifact.
cards.originalText: Take any number of artifacts of your choice from target player's graveyard and place them on top of that player's library, in any order.

cards.name: Energy Flux
cards.text: All artifacts have "At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice this artifact unless you pay {2}."
cards.originalText: All artifacts in play now require an upkeep cost of {2} in addition to any other upkeep costs they may have. If the upkeep cost for an artifact is not paid, the artifact must be discarded.

cards.name: Gate to Phyrexia
cards.text: Sacrifice a creature: Destroy target artifact. Activate this ability only during your upkeep and only once each turn.
cards.flavor: "The warm rain of grease on my face immediately made it clear I had entered Phyrexia." —Jarsyl, Diary
cards.originalText: Sacrifice one of your creatures during your upkeep to destroy any one artifact. You may not sacrifice a creature that is already on its way to the graveyard.

cards.name: Haunting Wind
cards.text: Whenever an artifact becomes tapped or a player activates an artifact's ability without {T} in its activation cost, Haunting Wind deals 1 damage to that artifact's controller.
cards.flavor: These devices lured so many spirits that sometimes entire battlefields would become haunted at once.
cards.originalText: Each time an artifact in play is tapped or its activation cost is paid, Haunting Wind does 1 damage to that artifact's controller. Is not triggered by continuous artifacts.

cards.name: Hurkyl's Recall
cards.text: Return all artifacts target player owns to their hand.
cards.flavor: This spell, attributed to Drafna, was actually the work of his wife Hurkyl.

rulings.text: Retrieves all artifacts owned by the target player regardless of who controls them. Ignores artifacts owned by other players even if target player has control of them.
It only returns artifacts which are on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: All artifacts in play owned by target player are returned to target player's hand. Any enchantments on those artifacts are discarded. Cannot be played during the damage-dealing phase of an attack.

cards.name: Phyrexian Gremlins
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Phyrexian Gremlins during your untap step.
{T}: Tap target artifact. It doesn't untap during its controller's untap step for as long as Phyrexian Gremlins remains tapped.

rulings.text: If the Gremlins somehow become an artifact and then tap themselves, they can never be untapped during the untap phase. They must be untapped by an external effect.
Only prevents the artifact from untapping during untap step. Ones that untap during upkeep are not inhibited.
The target artifact can't untap if the Gremlins and the artifact are tapped during untap, even if it is your artifact, and you plan on untapping the Gremlins.
The effect does not end if the target stops being valid. For example, if it stops being an artifact.
Can target a tapped artifact.

cards.originalText: Tap Gremlins to tap an artifact. As long as Gremlins remain tapped and in play, that artifact does not untap as normal during its controller's untap phase. You may choose not to untap Gremlins during your untap phase.

cards.name: Power Artifact
cards.text:
Enchant artifact
Enchanted artifact's activated abilities cost {2} less to activate. This effect can't reduce the amount of mana an ability costs to activate to less than one mana.

rulings.text: Only affects the generic mana part of activation costs. Colored parts of mana costs are not affected.
Can be placed on artifacts with no or zero activation costs, but this has no effect on them. It does not increase the cost to one.
Can't reduce Snow mana costs.
Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText: The activation cost of target artifact is reduced by {2}. If this would reduce target artifact's activation cost below {1}, target artifact's activation cost becomes {1}. Power Artifact has no effect on artifacts that have no activation cost or whose activation cost is {0}.

cards.name: Priest of Yawgmoth
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Add an amount of {B} equal to the sacrificed artifact's converted mana cost.
cards.originalText: Tap to add an amount of black mana equal to target artifact's casting cost to your mana pool. This effect is played as an interrupt. Target artifact, which must belong to you, is discarded. This artifact cannot be one that is already on its way to the graveyard, and artifact creatures killed this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Reconstruction
cards.text: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: Tedious research made the Sages of the College of Lat-Nam adept in repairing broken artifacts.
cards.originalText: Bring one artifact from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Sage of Lat-Nam
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Draw a card.
cards.originalText: Tap to draw a card from your library. Each time you use this ability, you must choose one of your artifacts in play and place it in the graveyard. This artifact cannot be one that is already on its way to the graveyard, and artifact creatures killed this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Transmute Artifact
cards.text: Sacrifice an artifact. If you do, search your library for an artifact card. If that card's converted mana cost is less than or equal to the sacrificed artifact's converted mana cost, put it onto the battlefield. If it's greater, you may pay {X}, where X is the difference. If you do, put it onto the battlefield. If you don't, put it into its owner's graveyard. Then shuffle your library.

rulings.text: Additional mana spent to cover the differences in mana costs is not part of the mana cost of this spell. It is spent during spell resolution.
The one from the library enters the battlefield when the spell is resolved, and this does not count as the casting of an artifact.
You can't sacrifice more than one artifact to this spell.
If the chosen artifact costs less than or the same as the sacrificed artifact, you simply put it onto the battlefield without paying any additional costs.
Because the "search" requires you to find a card with certain characteristics, you don't have to find the card if you don't want to.
The sacrifice of an artifact is an effect of the spell, not a cost, which means it happens as the spell resolves. If Transmute Artifact is countered, you do not have to sacrifice an artifact.

cards.originalText: Search through your library for one artifact and immediately place it into play; also, choose any artifact in play that you control and place it in its owner's graveyard. If the new artifact has a casting cost greater than that of the discarded one, you must pay the difference or Transmute Artifact fails and both artifacts are discarded. Shuffle your library after playing this card.

cards.name: Xenic Poltergeist
cards.text: {T}: Until your next upkeep, target noncreature artifact becomes an artifact creature with power and toughness each equal to its converted mana cost.

rulings.text: Wears off at the beginning of the upkeep, not during upkeep.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

cards.originalText: Tap to turn target non-creature artifact into an artifact creature with both power and toughness equal to its casting cost. This transformation lasts until your next upkeep; target retains all its original abilities as well.

cards.name: Yawgmoth Demon
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may sacrifice an artifact. If you don't, tap Yawgmoth Demon and it deals 2 damage to you.

rulings.text: The sacrificing of an artifact is not mandatory. You can choose not to sacrifice an artifact but will pay the consequences.

cards.originalText:
Flying, first strike
During your upkeep, choose one of your artifacts in play and place it in the graveyard, or Yawgmoth Demon becomes tapped and deals 2 points of damage to you. Artifact creatures destroyed this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Argothian Pixies
cards.text:
Argothian Pixies can't be blocked by artifact creatures.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Argothian Pixies by artifact creatures.
cards.flavor: After the rape of Argoth Forest during the rule of the artificers, the Pixies of Argoth bent their magic to more practical ends.
cards.originalText: Cannot be blocked by artifact creatures. Any damage Argothian Pixies take from artifact creatures is reduced to 0.

cards.name: Argothian Treefolk
cards.text: Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Argothian Treefolk by artifact sources.
cards.flavor:
Haunting cries we hear in our dreams
As the forest dies, a death from
machines.
cards.originalText: Any damage Argothian Treefolk take from an artifact source is reduced to 0.

cards.name: Citanul Druid
cards.text: Whenever an opponent casts an artifact spell, put a +1/+1 counter on Citanul Druid.
cards.flavor: Driven mad by the fall of Argoth, the Citanul Druids found peace only in battle.

rulings.text: In multiplayer games it affects all players.

cards.originalText: Druid gains a +1/+1 counter each time opponent casts an artifact.

cards.name: Crumble
cards.text: Destroy target artifact. It can't be regenerated. That artifact's controller gains life equal to its converted mana cost.
cards.flavor: The spirits of Argoth grant new life to those who repent the folly of enslaving their labors to devices.

rulings.text: If the target artifact becomes illegal before resolution, the player does not gain any life.

cards.originalText: Destroy target artifact; artifact creatures may not regenerate. Artifact's controller gains life points equal to target artifact's casting cost.

cards.name: Gaea's Avenger
cards.text: Gaea's Avenger's power and toughness are each equal to 1 plus the number of artifacts your opponents control.
cards.flavor: After the destruction of Argoth, Gaea was willing to instill a portion of her own powers into some of her more vengeful followers.

rulings.text: In multi-player games it counts artifacts of all opponents.

cards.originalText: The *s below are the number of artifacts opponent has in play.

cards.name: Powerleech
cards.text: Whenever an artifact an opponent controls becomes tapped or an opponent activates an artifact's ability without {T} in its activation cost, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: The Forest of Argoth has developed a resistance to mechanical intrusion.

rulings.text: In a multi-player game it affects all opponents.

cards.originalText: Gain 1 life whenever one of opponent's artifacts becomes tapped, or whenever the activation cost of one of opponent's artifacts is paid. Is not triggered by continuous artifacts.

cards.name: Titania's Song
cards.text: Each noncreature artifact loses all abilities and becomes an artifact creature with power and toughness each equal to its converted mana cost. If Titania's Song leaves the battlefield, this effect continues until end of turn.

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

cards.originalText: All non-creature artifacts in play lose all their usual abilities and become artifact creatures with toughness and power both equal to their casting costs. If Titania's Song leaves play, artifacts return to normal just before the untap phase of the next turn.

cards.name: Artifact Blast
cards.text: Counter target artifact spell.
cards.flavor: The first line of defense against Urza and Mishra, the Artifact Blast achieved widespread fame until an unlucky mage discovered it was useless on the devices the brothers had already created.
cards.originalText: Counters any artifact as it is being cast.

cards.name: Atog
cards.text: Sacrifice an artifact: Atog gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.originalText: {0}: +2/+2 until end of turn. Each time you use this ability, you must choose one of your artifacts in play and place it in the graveyard. This artifact cannot be one that is already on its way to the graveyard, and artifact creatures killed this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Detonate
cards.text: Destroy target artifact with converted mana cost X. It can't be regenerated. Detonate deals X damage to that artifact's controller.

rulings.text: If the artifact becomes an illegal target before resolution, then no damage is done.

cards.originalText: Targets any artifact; X is the casting cost of target artifact. Target artifact is destroyed, and Detonate does X points of damage to artifact's controller. Artifact creatures destroyed in this manner may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Dwarven Weaponsmith
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.
cards.originalText: Tap during your upkeep to add a permanent +1/+1 counter to any creature. Each time you use this ability, you must choose one of your artifacts in play and place it in the graveyard. This artifact cannot be one that is already on its way to the graveyard, and artifact creatures killed in this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Goblin Artisans
cards.text: {T}: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, draw a card. If you lose the flip, counter target artifact spell you control that isn't the target of an ability from another creature named Goblin Artisans.
cards.originalText: You may tap Goblin Artisans as you cast an artifact. Then flip a coin; opponent calls heads or tails while coin is in the air. If the flip ends up in opponent's favor, your artifact is countered. Otherwise, draw another card from your library. You can only use this ability once for each time you cast an artifact.

cards.name: Orcish Mechanics
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Orcish Mechanics deals 2 damage to any target.
cards.originalText: Tap to do 2 points of damage to any target. Each time you use this ability, you must choose one of your artifacts in play and place it in the graveyard. This artifact cannot be one already on its way to the graveyard, and artifact creatures killed this way may not be regenerated.

cards.name: Shatterstorm
cards.text: Destroy all artifacts. They can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor: Chains of leaping fire and sizzling lightning laid waste the artificers' handiwork, sparing not a single device.
cards.originalText:
All artifacts in play are discarded.
Artifact creatures cannot be regenerated.

cards.name: Argivian Archaeologist
cards.text: {W}{W}, {T}: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: Fascinated by the lore of ancient struggles, the Archaeologist searches incessantly for remnants of an earlier, more powerful era.
cards.originalText: {W}{W}: Tap to bring one artifact from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Argivian Blacksmith
cards.text: {T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to target artifact creature this turn.
cards.flavor: Through years of study and training, the Blacksmiths of Argive became adept at reassembling the mangled remains of the strange, mechanical creatures abounding in their native land.
cards.originalText: Tap to prevent up to 2 damage to target artifact creature.

cards.name: Artifact Ward
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked by artifact creatures.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to enchanted creature by artifact sources.
Enchanted creature can't be the target of abilities from artifact sources.
cards.originalText: Target creature cannot be blocked by artifact creatures, and any damage taken from an artifact source is reduced to 0. Target creature is unaffected by any artifact effects that target it.

cards.name: Circle of Protection: Artifacts
cards.text: {2}: The next time an artifact source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.
cards.originalText: {2}: Prevents all damage against you from any one artifact source. If a source does damage to you more than once in a turn, you must pay {2} each time you want to prevent the damage.

cards.name: Damping Field
cards.text: Players can't untap more than one artifact during their untap steps.
cards.flavor: Eventually, mages learned to harness the power of natural damping fields and use it for their own ends.

rulings.text: Artifact creatures are artifacts. They are affected so only one may untap.
Damping Field does not prevent artifacts being untapped by spells or abilities at other times.

cards.originalText: Players may not untap more than one artifact during each of their own untap phases.

cards.name: Martyrs of Korlis
cards.text: As long as Martyrs of Korlis is untapped, all damage that would be dealt to you by artifacts is dealt to Martyrs of Korlis instead.

rulings.text: If you have multiple Martyrs of Korlis, you can decide which one receives the redirected damage each time artifact damage would be dealt to you.

cards.originalText: Unless Martyrs of Korlis is tapped, any damage done to you by artifacts is instead applied to Martyrs of Korlis. You may not take this damage yourself, though you may prevent it if possible. No more than one Bodyguard of your choice can take damage for you in this manner each turn.

cards.name: Reverse Polarity
cards.text: You gain X life, where X is twice the damage dealt to you so far this turn by artifacts.
cards.originalText: All damage done to you so far this turn by artifacts is retroactively added to your life total instead of subtracted. Further damage this turn is treated normally.

cards.name: Mishra's Factory
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes a 2/2 Assembly-Worker artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
{T}: Target Assembly-Worker creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: If another player takes control of the Factory while it is animated, that player keeps control until the control effect ends. They do not lose control just because the card stops being an Assembly-Worker. Note that Auras which steal cards will go to the graveyard if the permanent they enchant is no longer valid.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it's already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.
Once turned into a creature, Mishra's Factory's last ability can target itself. If it's already blocking, this won't remove it from combat.
If you turn Mishra's Factory into a creature but haven't controlled it continuously since your most recent turn began, you won't be able to activate its first or last ability.

cards.originalText:
Tap to add 1 colorless mana to your mana pool or give any Assembly Worker +1/+1 until end of turn.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes an Assembly Worker, a 2/2 artifact creature, until end of turn. Assembly Worker is still considered a land as well.

cards.name: Mishra's Factory
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes a 2/2 Assembly-Worker artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
{T}: Target Assembly-Worker creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: If another player takes control of the Factory while it is animated, that player keeps control until the control effect ends. They do not lose control just because the card stops being an Assembly-Worker. Note that Auras which steal cards will go to the graveyard if the permanent they enchant is no longer valid.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it's already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.
Once turned into a creature, Mishra's Factory's last ability can target itself. If it's already blocking, this won't remove it from combat.
If you turn Mishra's Factory into a creature but haven't controlled it continuously since your most recent turn began, you won't be able to activate its first or last ability.

cards.originalText:
Tap to add 1 colorless mana to your mana pool or give any Assembly Worker +1/+1 until end of turn.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes an Assembly Worker, a 2/2 artifact creature, until end of turn. Assembly Worker is still considered a land as well.

cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes a 2/2 Assembly-Worker artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
{T}: Target Assembly-Worker creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes an Assembly Worker, a 2/2 artifact creature, until end of turn. Assembly Worker is still considered a land as well.

cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes a 2/2 Assembly-Worker artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
{T}: Target Assembly-Worker creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: If another player takes control of the Factory while it is animated, that player keeps control until the control effect ends. They do not lose control just because the card stops being an Assembly-Worker. Note that Auras which steal cards will go to the graveyard if the permanent they enchant is no longer valid.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it's already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

Tap to add 1 colorless mana to your mana pool or give any Assembly Worker +1/+1 until end of turn.
{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes an Assembly Worker, a 2/2 artifact creature, until end of turn. Assembly Worker is still considered a land as well.
